title: The ice surface in premelting and freezing: transition dynamics and metastable states. (arXiv:2211.01787v1 [physics.chem-ph])
description: The premelting of ice is well known, but not about how the premelted and solid surfaces convert into each other. In this work, the transition dynamics between two phases are revealed with large-scale molecular dynamics simulations. Supercooling and superheating states exist in the transition, and are overcome by nucleation-like processes. The natural inhomogeneity of ice surface enhances nuclei formation, while it only accelerates premelting but not freezing. Furthermore, the complete freezing of ice surfaces may be hindered by the stacking order mismatch between nuclei. This work points out the importance of metastable states in premelting studies, and calls attention to their potential effects on related physics.
